Event title: Shop till you drop, the changing face of retail in Leeds.
Event description: Retail is an unavoidable part of modern life.  Whether you need something for tea, a new outfit, or to decorate your bedroom, it is difficult to get away from shopping.  This study day is an opportunity to find out more about some of the history of retail in Leeds – from the glamorous to the grimy. The morning will feature an illustrated talk on retail and some of the changes that have happened over the last 150 years, including local examples such as the famous Victorian Arcades and their modern revival.  In the afternoon we will explore some of the museum ephemera collections relating to retail.  Ever wondered what a Victorian sanitary ware catalogue looked like, wanted to peruse a 1920’s bulb catalogue, or perhaps you would just like to remind yourself what Argos were selling in 1973?  If so, this is the perfect opportunity for you to come along and find out more.

Come learn about the changing face of Leeds in the 1800s, from humble back-to-backs, to grand public buildings and statues. Who were the architects responsible for transforming a modest Georgian town into a great Victorian City? How did the town’s buildings reflect the lives of its inhabitants? And how much of this Victorian heritage remains today? Come and explore changes to Leeds’ architectural fabric through collections not on display, including rare maps, prints, photographs, bills and letterheads. With Patrick Bourne, Assistant Curator of Community History

Have a make-over in a decade of your choice, or dress in costumes from the recent past.
Join us as we perform music and dances from different eras, or simply share your reminiscences and photos with us.
Whether ‘your  era’ is the fabulous fifties, swinging sixties,  nineties, noughties or now, there’ll be something for everyone.
Come along to see how earlier years or just interested to see what the generations before you got up to when they were your age.
Drop in at any time between 10am and 3pm to participate. Open to anybody aged 13 and above, and young at heart.
10-11am Fabulous Fifties hour
11am-12pm Swinging Sixties hour
12pm-1pm Smashing Seventies hour
1pm-2pm Awesome Eighties hour
2-3pm Nifty Nineties hour
3-4pm Noughties to now

A Kirkstall Abbey Market with a difference. The Medieval Congress presents 'Medieval Kirkstall for its modern communities’. There will be cookery demonstrations, talks about the monastic history of the Abbey focusing on hospitality, eating, feasting and fasting. Tours of the abbey, food sample tastings and ‘hungry gap’ food displays.

Bring you little one and their bike to celebrate the fun of the Tour de France with fun races in our cloister. There will be mini grass courses and some big races around the whole cloister plus games and lots more fun.

Our weekly under 5's session has a dragon theme for the summer holidays. Bring along your mini dragon for fun crafts and activities in the abbey. Please be prepared that we do get messy and we like to go outside and explore in nice weather. Older siblings welcome.
Each Wednesday of the school holidays we will be putting out a selection of games in the cloister for people to help themselves and have fun.
Come along to the abbey, bring a picnic and meet our friendly dragon Barry. Just make sure he doesn't eat your sandwiches!

Take yourself back to the golden age and enjoy an Edwardian gala at Lotherton Hall.  Face painting, side shows and activities. Live music from Cawthorne Brass Band playing in front of the house next to the chapel. Plus we will be joined by Pheonix Crafts with stalls of a selection of handmade gifts, crafts, jewellery, bath products and much more for sale.

Event title: Talk and tea with the curator
Event description:
The difference between Florence Nightingale and her cousin Marianne Nicholson.
Stephanie Davies will talk about the differences between Florence Nightingale and her cousin Marianne Nicholson, how despite being inseparable as young cousins they chose opposite paths in life. Followed by afternoon tea.
This month's theme is 'Beside the Seaside', we will be bringing the summer holidays to Lotherton with sandy crafts and play
Chapel Service
Six weeks of themed fun! Discover a new theme each week as we host a variety of family activities, crafts and trails throughout the whole summer holidays. Check the website and Facebook for details.
Build a butterfly feeder and learn how you can give nature a home
Meet outside Stables Courtyard
All the fun of the fifties and sixties with live music, outdoor games and spot prizes for the best outfits.  One person admitted free if you come in a pre 1960's vehicle

Event title: "They Gave" - a talk about the Gascoigne and Galton family of Lotherton Hall
Event description: Michael Copeland great nephew of Gwendolen Gascoigne, and Pauline Robson local historian, will talk about the Gascoigne and Galton Philanthropic works during their time of social influence. Followed by tea and Coffee in the servants Hall.

Welcome the autumn months with a chance to pick and try rare apples from Lotherton's own orchard with over 100 northern apple varieties to try including apple juice and cider tasting, an ‘apple and spoon race’, garden games, brass band and vegetable carving crafts

Enjoy an afternoon concert with Mendelssohn, the famous Victorian composer. The music is taken from a small private concert attended by Lotherton Hall's Marianne Nicholson in 1845. During the same evening, to entertain the ladies, Mendelssohn wrote words to his Spring Song . The great composer left the words written in pencil on top of the piano and Marianne Nicholson kept them in her scrap book as a memento. Spring Song will be performed by soprano, Jane Troughton, for the first time since they were sang that evening by Adelaide Kemble using the very same words written by Mendelssohn himself. Followed by tea and coffee in the Servants Hall
Drop-in easy arts and crafts, story time and play aimed at under-5s with their adults. This month we will go on a nature walk to inspire our nature art work.

A study day to coincide with the exhibition Our Cousin Florence at Lotherton Hall. The day will explore the homes of Florence Nightingale, those of her cousins and the role that they played in her development as the innovator of modern Nursing. We will also look at some of the medical and surgical problems Florence and her nurses faced at Scutari hospital in the Crimea. Speakers will be: Michael Crumplin FRCS (Eng. and Ed.), FRHistS, FINS, FHS. Mick is a retired consultant surgeon. He is an international author and has acted as medical advisor for media programmes and publications. He is an Hon. Curator and Archivist at the Royal College of Surgeons of England, and is a Trustee of the Waterloo Association. 
Dr Russ Foster was a teacher at Embley Park, the former Hampshire home of the Nightingales for 28  years, including 20 years as Head of History & Politics. At Embley he organised the international commemorative conference Florence Nightingale Influence and Inspiration in 2010. His published work includes a paper on William Nightingale and a guide to FN’s life at Embley. Russ was elected a Fellow of the Royal Historical society in 2005. 
Dr Adam White art historian and museum curator. He has worked at the Leeds Museums and Galleries since 1983. Since 1994 he has been based at Lotherton Hall and Temple Newsam House. He is Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries of London and has published widely on British art, particularly sculpture. He is currently the Hon Curator of Collections at Lotherton Hall in Yorkshire.

Event title: Talk and tea with the curator, Natalie Raw, Curator of Costumes, Leeds Museums and Galleries
Event description: Find out about the fashions followed by the young Florence Nightingale and her cousins with Natalie Raw, the Curator of Costumes for Leeds Museums and Galleries, followed by afternoon tea.
Drop-in easy arts and crafts, story time and play aimed at under-5s with their adults. This month we will be making mini scarecrows ready for Halloween!

Back and better than ever but beware we aim to scare! Follow the clues around Lotherton Hall and see the popular spooky scarecrows on display. Don't forget to visit the Witches' Cottage and try your hand at the creepy crafts.

Dress up your little monsters and join us for our first Halloween weekend. Spot prizes for the best costumes, spooky scarecrow trail, face painting, creepy crafts and the chance to meet some ghostly characters in the Hall.

Event title: Talk and Tea with the curator. Stephanie Davies, Assistant Community Curator, Lotherton Hall
Event description: Come to a talk about the famous literary friends of Florence Nightingale and  Marianne Nicholson and how the cousins influenced their friends Elisabeth Gaskall and Charles Dickens. Followed by afternoon tea.

Event title: Romanticism Rediscovered – performance and discussion of the music of Chopin and Liszt in the style of the 19th century
Event description: Soiree with scholar-musician Andrew Snedden, specialist in 19th century performance practice. Andrew will perform and discuss works by Liszt and Chopin, who composed and performed on instruments like the Erard grand piano at Lotherton. He will also explore the characteristics of Erards; how they differ from a modern grand piano and why a historically accurate playing technique is important in order to perform compositions in a manner their composers intended. Followed by tea, coffee and cake.

Event title: Florence Nightingale, the Heroine of the Crimean War'  A concert and afternoon tea
Event description: Come to the historical Concert, 'Florence Nightingale, the Heroine of the Crimean War'. An original musical production from the 1860s celebrating the Life and work of Florence Nightingale. Performed by Jane Troughton and Company followed by afternoon tea.
Drop-in easy arts and crafts, story time and play aimed at under-5s with their adults. This month we will be inspired by all things that glitter!

Event title: The Mystery of Florence Nightingale Shaw by Pauline Robson, local historian
Event description: Come and hear the story of Florence Nightingale Shaw, relative of Florence Nightingale. Learn  about the unusual event that came to make her one of the most infamous mysteries of the early 1900s. Followed by tea and coffee.
Details TBC for now
Date and time: Fri 25th Nov - Fri 23rd Dec TBC times etc.

Event description: Come on a tour with Stephanie Davies through the ‘Our Cousin Florence’ exhibition and discover Florence Nightingale’s connection to the Gascoigne family.  In 2011, while conducting research on the Gascoigne family, Stephanie rediscovered some letters from Florence Nightingale addressed to her cousin Marianne Nicholson, Gwendolen Gascoigne's mother. They were found in the attic at Trelissick Manor Cornwall, home of Gwendolen’s older sister, Eveline. Hear first-hand the amazing story.
